body.p: Last year in September eLife, Substance and Stencila started the Reproducible Document Stack Project with the goal to develop the technology required to support the Reproducible Manuscript through authoring and publication. Today we want to share with you a functional prototype implementing that vision.

The article you are reading right now was written in Stencila, an open source office suite designed for reproducible research. It allows authoring of interactive, data-driven publications in visual interfaces.

sec.title: Document Archive (Dar)
sec.p: A publication is represented as a self-contained archive of documents and assets, building on open standards, such as JATS XML, which have been widely adopted within the publishing industry. Together with experts from open science communities we defined extensions to add source code, data and methods to a journal-ready manuscript.

sec.title: Living Documents
sec.p: In order to allow scientists transition to fully reproducible publications, we are taking the approach of building on the traditional manuscript and bringing it to life by including data and methods to generate reproducible elements such as interactive plots.
The following image is produced based on data in a spreadsheet that is included in the publication. Note, that you can inspect the source code of the article by clicking on "Reproduce".

caption.title: Ice Cream Sales
caption.p: This interactive Plotly visualisation shows Ice Cream Sales vs Temperature using a small sample dataset.

sec.p: The following image uses Mt Bruno Elevation data, which is included as a spreadsheet and is rendered using Plotly, a browser-based visualization toolkit.
Note that the graphic is interactive and you can rotate and zoom using the mouse.

sec.title: Support for R, Python and other languages
sec.p: The Reproducible Document Stack is designed to work with different programming languages. Users can either rely on an existing function library provided by Stencila, or add custom code in a number of available languages (e.g. R, Python, Javascript, SQL). The following figure has been generated R (see [1] for the original figure).

caption.title: Digital gene expression analysis
caption.p: TODO Nokome: Connect R context and

P493-6 cells grown in the presence of tetracycline (Tet) for 72 hr for repression of the conditional pmyc-tet construct, were switched into Tet-free growth medium to induce c-Myc expression. Cells were cultured in two separate lots of serum. Transcripts/cell estimates from NanoString nCounter gene expression assays (1369 genes assay) for active (left) and silent (right) genes at 0, 1, and 24 hr after release from Tet. Active genes expressed greater than one transcript/cell. Silent genes expressed less than 0.5 transcript/cell. Box and whisker plots with median represented as the line through the box and whiskers representing values within 1.5 IQR of the first and third quartile. Cells grown in serum lot one: active genes = 708, silent genes = 580. Cells grown in serum lot two: active genes = 719, silent genes = 573.

alternatives.code: s <- min(1000, 500) x <- runif(s) y <- x + runif(s) z <- y + rnorm(s) plot(x, y, cex=z*2, col=rainbow(length(z), alpha=0.5)[rank(x+z)], pch=16)

sec.title: Interoperability with existing tools and workflows
sec.p: The Reproducible Document Stack is developed to complement existing tools, not to replace them. We are working with the communities of established open source tools to improve interoperability. We aim to support file formats commonly used by researchers for reproducibility such as Jupyter Notebooks, RMarkdown and more.

element-citation.article-title: Replication Study: Transcriptional amplification in tumor cells with elevated c-Myc
